facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 543 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 543 of 1962. Appeal from the judgement

facts.text: Appeal from the judgement and order dated November 26, 1959 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 678 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgement and order dated November 26, 1959 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 678 1957. Bishan Narain and N. N.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 12, 1964 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: March 12, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by- AYYANGAR, J.-This is an appeal on a certificate of fitness granted under Art. 133

facts.text: Appellant's father owned considerable agricultural property in Pakistan and moved to India on partition with family.

anchor.surface_text: The father of the appellant owned company- siderable agricultural property in Pakistan and he with the members of his family moved over to India on partition.

facts.text: Appellant's father died in 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the appellants father had died in 1952 and the allotment made was actually to the

facts.text: Allotment made on December 29, 1955 by Managing Officer to appellant on quasi-permanent tenure of Khasra Nos. 880, 881 and 882 within municipal area of Kharar.

anchor.surface_text: He had still some unsatisfied claim for allotment and on December 29, 1955 he was allotted by the Managing Officer on quasi-permanent tenure Khasra Nos. 880, 881 and 882 which were within the municipal area of Kharar with the regularity of which allotment alone this appeal is companycerned.

facts.text: Sanad issued to appellant on December 31, 1955 by Managing Officer.

anchor.surface_text: On the allotment being made, a sanad was issued to the appellant on December 31, 1955 by the Managing Officer.

facts.text: Respondents Nos. 4 and 5 raised disputes when appellant tried to take possession of the lands.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant tried to take possession of these lands, disputes were raised by respondent L P  D  ISCI-7 Nos. 4 and 5.

facts.text: Respondents 4 and 5 claimed possession from long anterior date and that property could not be subject of valid allotment.

anchor.surface_text: They were number displaced persons but they claimed that they had been in possession of this property from a long anterior date from which they companyld number be disturbed and also that the property companyld number be the subject of a valid allotment.

facts.text: Respondents 4 and 5 moved Assistant Settlement Commissioner for cancellation of allotment, which was allowed.

anchor.surface_text: These respondents moved the Assistant Settlement Commissioner for cancellation of the allotment and this appeal was allowed by the officer who found that the land companyprised in these three khasra numbers were within an urban area

facts.text: Assistant Settlement Commissioner cancelled allotment finding land in urban area per r. 2(h) of Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: within the meaning of r. 2 h  of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 and companysequently that the allotment to the appellant was companytrary to law. He, therefore, cancelled the allotment.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Chief Settlement Commissioner in revision, unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter applied to the Chief Settlement Commissioner in revision and number being successful there moved the High Court by a, petition under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed petition under Arts. 226 and 227.

anchor.surface_text: As stated earlier, this petition was dismissed and it is the companyrectness of this dismissal that is challenged in the appeal before us.

facts.text: Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 published on May 21, 1955 and came into force then.

anchor.surface_text: These rules were published on May 21, 1955 when they came into force. Rule 2 h  the validity of which is impugned in these proceedings is a rule companytaining the definitions.

facts.text: Allotment to appellant made after May 21, 1955 (not in dispute).

anchor.surface_text: Pausng here, it would be useful to state two matters which are number in dispute  1  that the allotment to the appellant was made on December 29, 1955, the sanad being issued two days later.

facts.text: Khasra Nos. 880, 881 and 882 included in urban limits on February 10, 1951 by extension of municipal area of Kharar (not in dispute).

anchor.surface_text: the other matter is that Khasra Nos. 880, 881 and 882 were included in urban limits on February 10, 1951 by the municipal area of Kharar being extended to companyer these plots.

facts.text: On date of allotment, land was in urban area and could not be validly allotted.

anchor.surface_text: It would, therefore, be obvious that on the date when the allotment was made, the allotted land was in an urban area and therefore it companyld number have been validly allotted.

facts.text: Appellant urged that rule 2(h) unconstitutional violating Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: The second point that he urged was, and this was in fact the main companytention raised before the High Court, that rule 2 h  of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 was unconstitutional as companytravening Art. 14 of the Constitution

facts.text: Court rejected contention that sanad gives indefeasible title.

anchor.surface_text: We have companysidered this point in Shri Mithoo Shahani and Ors. v. The Union of India and Ors.  1  which was pronounced on March 10, 1964 and for the reasons there stated this submission has to be rejected.

facts.text: Court found no substance in argument that rule 2(h) violates Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: We companysider that there is numbersubstance in this argument. In fact, we are unable to appreciate the ground on which the companytention is being urged.

issues.text: Whether after the Managing Officer granted a sanad on December 31, 1955 in the name of the President of India, the appellant obtained an indefeasible title to the property and that this title could not be displaced except on grounds contained in the sanad itself even in the event of the order of allotment being set aside on appeal or revision

anchor.surface_text: that after the Managing Officer granted a sanad on December 31, 1955 in the name of the President of India, the appellant obtained an indefeasible title to the property

issues.text: Whether rule 2(h) of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 was unconstitutional as contravening Art. 14 of the Constitution and so the original allotment to the appellant must be held to be lawful

anchor.surface_text: that rule 2 h  of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 was unconstitutional as contravening Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bishan Narain, learned Counsel for the appellant urged in the main two companytentions in support of the appeal. arguments.claim: Rule 2(h) of 1955 Rules unconstitutional contravening Art.14, so original allotment lawful

anchor.surface_text: The second point that he urged was, and this was in fact the main companytention raised before the High Court, that rule 2 h  of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 was unconstitutional as companytravening Art. 14 of the Constitution and so the original allotment to the appellant must be held to be lawful.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: his submission has to be rejected. The second point that he urged was, and this was in fact the main companytention raised before the High Court, that

arguments.court_reasoning: No substance; unable to appreciate ground; prospective operation drawing line at commencement date not discriminatory; every law must have beginning

arguments.claim: Rules competently made under s.40 of 1954 Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 40 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954 enables the Central Government by Notification in the Official Gazette to make rules to carry out the purposes of the Act... It was number suggested that the rules of 1955 were number companypetently made under s. 40.

arguments.claim: Proviso to r.2(h) uses 1947 urban limits only for pre-21 May 1955 quasi-permanent allotments in Punjab/PEPSU; post-allotments use current limits

anchor.surface_text: These rules were published on May 21, 1955 when they came into force. Rule 2 h  ... Provided that in the case of the quasi-perma- nent allotment of rural agricultural lands already made in the States of Punjab and Patiala and East Punjab States Union, the limits of an urban area shall be as they existed on the 15th August, 1947.

arguments.claim: Prospective operation of rule drawing dividing line at commencement date does not violate Art.14; every law must have a beginning

anchor.surface_text: It is the discrimination that is said to companysist in the rule having drawn a dividing line at the date when it came into force... Every law must have a beginning or time from which it operates, and numberrule which seeks to change the law can be held invalid for the mere reason that it effects an alteration An the law.

holdings.text: The submission that the sanad conferred an indefeasible title to the property which could not be displaced even if the order of allotment was set aside on appeal or revision has to be rejected

anchor.surface_text: We have considered this point in Shri Mithoo Shahani and Ors. v. The Union of India and Ors.  1  which was pronounced on March 10, 1964 and for the reasons there stated this submission has to be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point considered and rejected following the decision in Shri Mithoo Shahani and Ors. v. The Union of India and Ors. pronounced on March 10, 1964

holdings.text: Rule 2(h) of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955 does not contravene Article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: We consider that there is nosubstance in this argument. In fact, we are unable to appreciate the ground on which the contention is being urged. Section 40 of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954 enables the Central Government by Notification in the Official Gazette to make rules to carry out the purposes of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule made competently under s.40; prospective operation drawing dividing line at commencement date not discriminatory under Art.14 as every law must have a beginning and cannot be invalidated merely for prospective effect

holdings.text: The allotted land was in an urban area on the date of allotment and therefore could not have been validly allotted under Rule 2(h)

anchor.surface_text: the other matter is that Khasra Nos. 880, 881 and 882 were included in urban limits on February 10, 1951 by the municipal area of Kharar being extended to cover these plots. It would, therefore, be obvious that on the date when the allotment was made, the allotted land was in an urban area and therefore it could not have been validly allotted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Khasra nos. included in municipal urban limits on Feb 10 1951; allotment made Dec 29 1955 after rules came into force on May 21 1955; proviso to r.2(h) applies only to pre-rules quasi-permanent allotments
